@BrainMaps.Comments: Area TEO was not described directly (pp. 49,75), however many subsequent authors refer to TEO "as described by von Bonin & Bailey". Therefore, TEO was added to BB47.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments: Area TEO was not described directly (pp. 49,75), however many subsequent authors refer to TEO "as described by von Bonin & Bailey". Therefore, TEO was added to BB47.

@InterMapRelations.Corrected_Why: Not clear where this statement comes from

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "IB: ... The fourth layer is fairly thick and contains small granules..." (p. 39) "IA: The small anterior insular area shows on the whole rather an 'unfinished' workmanship... The fourth layer is just hinted at by the presence of a few scattered granules." (p. 39)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: In location and cytoarchitecture, area IB of BB47 seems to correspond to area Ig of MM82a.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "IB: ... The fourth layer is fairly thick and contains small granules..." (p. 39) "IA: The small anterior insular area shows on the whole rather an 'unfinished' workmanship... The fourth layer is just hinted at by the presence of a few scattered granules." (p. 39)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: In location and cytoarchitecture, area IA of BB47 seems to correspond to a combination of areas Ia-p and Idg of MM82a.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "IB: ... The fourth layer is fairly thick and contains small granules..." (p. 39) "IA: The small anterior insular area shows on the whole rather an 'unfinished' workmanship... The fourth layer is just hinted at by the presence of a few scattered granules." (p. 39)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: In location and cytoarchitecture, area IA of BB47 seems to correspond to a combination of areas Ia-p and Idg of MM82a.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: p. 68: "PB...occupies the entire posterior wall of the central sulcus, except a narrow strip in the depth [area PA]...At the upper extremity of the central sulcus PB spreads out on the surface posterior to the sulcus and then down the medial surface of the hemisphere to the upper lip of the cingulate sulcus..."

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Impression gained by the comparison of the two maps.
Impression gained by the comparison of the two maps.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "IB: ... The fourth layer is fairly thick and contains small granules..." (p. 39) "IA: The small anterior insular area shows on the whole rather an 'unfinished' workmanship... The fourth layer is just hinted at by the presence of a few scattered granules." (p. 39) "[In insular cortex] Brodmann distinguishes four areas, which he numbers 13, 14, 15, and 16... He has photographs of which 13 and 14 (Tafel 8) show an internal granular layer and the other two little or none. Area 16, which lies adjacent to the Regio olfactoria, resembles allocortex." (pp. 78-79)

"IB: ... The fourth layer is fairly thick and contains small granules..." (p. 39) "IA: The small anterior insular area shows on the whole rather an 'unfinished' workmanship... The fourth layer is just hinted at by the presence of a few scattered granules." (p. 39) "[In insular cortex] Brodmann distinguishes four areas, which he numbers 13, 14, 15, and 16... He has photographs of which 13 and 14 (Tafel 8) show an internal granular layer and the other two little or none. Area 16, which lies adjacent to the Regio olfactoria, resembles allocortex." (pp. 78-79)

"IB: ... The fourth layer is fairly thick and contains small granules..." (p. 39) "IA: The small anterior insular area shows on the whole rather an 'unfinished' workmanship... The fourth layer is just hinted at by the presence of a few scattered granules." (p. 39) "[In insular cortex] Brodmann distinguishes four areas, which he numbers 13, 14, 15, and 16... He has photographs of which 13 and 14 (Tafel 8) show an internal granular layer and the other two little or none. Area 16, which lies adjacent to the Regio olfactoria, resembles allocortex." (pp. 78-79)

"IB: ... The fourth layer is fairly thick and contains small granules..." (p. 39) "IA: The small anterior insular area shows on the whole rather an 'unfinished' workmanship... The fourth layer is just hinted at by the presence of a few scattered granules." (p. 39) "[In insular cortex] Brodmann distinguishes four areas, which he numbers 13, 14, 15, and 16... He has photographs of which 13 and 14 (Tafel 8) show an internal granular layer and the other two little or none. Area 16, which lies adjacent to the Regio olfactoria, resembles allocortex." (pp. 78-79)

BB47, p. 67: "In the depth of the central sulcus, the agranular cortex of FA changes into a thinner laminated type. The two granular layers appear and layer V clears. We may call this most anterior parietal cortex PA.Throughout most of the central sulcus...PA is a very narrow zone in the depth of the posterior wall." VV19, p. 374: "...so haben wir...jenen Rindenabschnitt, welchen Brodmann als Übergang zwischen seinen Feldern 4 und 3 bechreibt...als 3a abgegliedert."

BB47, p. 67: "In the depth of the central sulcus, the agranular cortex of FA changes into a thinner laminated type. The two granular layers appear and layer V clears. We may call this most anterior parietal cortex PA.Throughout most of the central sulcus...PA is a very narrow zone in the depth of the posterior wall." VV19, p. 374: "...so haben wir...jenen Rindenabschnitt, welchen Brodmann als Übergang zwischen seinen Feldern 4 und 3 bechreibt...als 3a abgegliedert." BB47, p. 68: "PB...occupies the entire posterior wall of the central sulcus, except a narrow strip in the depth [area PA]...At the upper extremity of the central sulcus PB spreads out on the surface posterior to the sulcus and then down the medial surface of the hemisphere to the upper lip of the cingulate sulcus..." - compare Figs. 65+66 of VV19.
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Due to the descriptions of PA and 3a, the position of 3b and PB in the posterior wall of the central sulcus,  and their highly similar cytoarchitectonic features (BB47: pp. 28-29; VV19: 368), it seems very probable that PB and 3b correspond to each other.
